I was trying to create some sequential plots today in R to analyse some MCMC simulations. I found the <code>par(ask=TRUE)</code> command very useful for looking at iterations of individual parameter values. Setting the ask graphical parameter to <code>TRUE</code> (before a for loop) allows you to update plots by clicking on the plotting device (in windows). Here is some example code to show how <code>par(ask=TRUE)</code> works.
```{r eval=FALSE}
xx <- rnorm(1000)
xx <- matrix(xx,10,100)
par(ask = TRUE)
plot(xx[1,], type="n", ylim=range(xx), ylab="")
for(i in 1:10){
   plot(xx[i,], ylim=range(xx), ylab="", type="l")
}
```
This will give the following output after each click:
<a href="http://gjabel.files.wordpress.com/2014/03/ask1.png"><img src="http://gjabel.files.wordpress.com/2014/03/ask1.png" alt="ask1" width="650" height="460" class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-1167" /></a>

If you want to keep previous plotted lines on the plot you can adapt the for loop in such a manner:
```{r eval=FALSE}
par(ask=TRUE)
plot(xx[1,], type="n", ylim=range(xx), ylab="")
for(i in 1:10){
   plot(xx[1,], ylim=range(xx), ylab="", type="l")
   for(j in 1:i){
      lines(xx[j,])
   }
}
```
This will give the following output after each click:
<a href="http://gjabel.files.wordpress.com/2014/03/ask2.png"><img src="http://gjabel.files.wordpress.com/2014/03/ask2.png" alt="ask2" width="650" height="460" class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-1168" /></a>
